text: the seabed in that part of the world is
like an underwater Alps
four and a half kilometers deep and with
two and a half kilometer high mountains
now that is the kind of terrain that
hides its secret and this is what
investigators are really after the black
boxes should solve this puzzle they'll
tell us what the aircraft was doing and
what the crew was saying on board but
how to find them well this piece of
American kitsch like a stingray will
lead the search it's called a towed
pinger locator but think of it as an
underwater microphone tuned to hear
signals from the black box locator
beacons a Royal Navy nuclear submarine
is also combing the area listening for
the same telltale pings now they might
get lucky but it's a long shot the
pinger batteries run out in a few days
and they'll be listening across an area
the size of Britain there's other
high-tech kit on standby as well this
underwater vehicle swims up and down
mapping the seabed but they won't start
using it until they find a piece of the
actual plane so they've got the best
tools available to find this airliner
but that doesn't mean it'll work they
had the same state of the art technology
five years ago to find the black boxes
from a French airliner that had crashed
into the Atlantic for a month they
trolled the area listening for signals
without realizing they even went over
the wreckage yet they heard nothing the
company that eventually helped find that
plane told me why in hindsight after the
wreckage was discovered it was revealed
that both fingers had failed and so it's
very similar to the situation faced now
with Malaysian Air 370 where you have no
information really on where the wreckage
could be on the ocean bottom and in
Malaysian air 370 it's an area about 20
to 20 times the size of the area we were
dealing with with Air France 447
another details changed recently that
throws new light on what happened here
in the cockpit moments before the
aircraft turned off course now
originally we were told the final words
to air traffic control were all right
good night
pilots told me that was too casual they
were suspicious maybe it was a clue
something was wrong
weeks later and seemingly out of the
blue the Malaysian suddenly changed
those final words - good night Malaysian
370 row a normal sign off that suggests
nothing was amiss the reality is if they
don't find floating wreckage fairly soon
they may never find this aircraft
